clinical_study.brief_title: Improving Keloids Using Targeted Ultraviolet-B Irradiation
clinical_study.official_title: Improving Keloids Using Targeted Ultraviolet-B Irradiation

brief_summary.textblock: Treatment of keloids with targeted Ultraviolet-Beta (UVB) radiation will improve the clinical appearance and induration of lesions.

clinical_study.why_stopped: PI wants to halt recruitment while reviewing preliminary data.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Each participant served as his/hers own control.

primary_outcome.measure: Clinical Appearance As Assessed by the Patient and Observer Scar Assessment (POSAS) Scale
primary_outcome.description: Investigators will evaluate the pre- and post-study clinical photographs of all participants. The grading investigator will grade the degree of improvement using the POSAS scale to measure the clinical appearance of the keloids

arm_group.description: Keloids that were randomized to the treatment group, were exposed to Narrowband-UVB (NB-UVB). Targeted UVB will be delivered to the keloid for up to 16 weeks using the Lumera UVB light phototherapy device (Daavlin, Bryan OH, USA).The affected skin will be irradiated using a hand-held fiber optic cable with an adjustable aperture.
Keloids that were randomized to a non treatment group, were not exposed to the NB-UVB light.

intervention.description: NB-UVB has an emission spectrum in the ultraviolet B range of 290-320 nm. The system consists of a light source, a spot handpiece, and a light guide that connects the handpiece to the light source. The light source has a Start/Stop switch for light beam activation. Activation can also be controlled remotely with a foot switch. The light source has a timer and an output level control to adjust the intensity of the ultraviolet light. This will be calibrated using a manufacturer-provided UV meter prior to every treatment to ensure accurate doses of ultraviolet light.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Participants must be 18 years old or over
- Participants must have a diagnosis of keloid
- No treatment with topical or intralesional steroids for 1 month prior to study
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients who are unable to provide informed consent
- A history of photosensitivity, lupus erythematosus, porphyria or current use of a known photosensitizing drug
- Unwillingness to stop with topical or intralesional steroids for 1 month prior to study
- A history of malignant melanoma
- A history of radiation therapy to area of interest
- Subjects who self-report that they are pregnant or nursing
